unicef-d1.source: United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division (2019). World Population Prospects 2019, Online Edition. Rev. 1. Proportion of urban population for regions and growth rates for total and urban population calculated by UNICEF.

unicef-d2.source: United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division (2019). World Population Prospects 2019, Online Edition. Rev. 1. Proportion of urban population for regions and growth rates for total and urban population calculated by UNICEF.

unicef-d3.source: United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division (2019). World Population Prospects 2019, Online Edition. Rev. 1. Proportion of urban population for regions and growth rates for total and urban population calculated by UNICEF.

unicef-d6.source: United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division (2019). World Population Prospects 2019, Online Edition. Rev. 1. Proportion of urban population for regions and growth rates for total and urban population calculated by UNICEF.

unicef-d7.def: The average number of live births a hypothetical cohort of women would have at the end of their reproductive period if they were subject during their whole lives to the fertility rates of a given period and if they were not subject to mortality. It is expressed as live births per woman.
unicef-d7.source: United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division (2019). World Population Prospects 2019, Online Edition. Rev. 1. Proportion of urban population for regions and growth rates for total and urban population calculated by UNICEF.

unicef-d8.def: Number of years newborn children would live if subject to the mortality risks prevailing for the cross section of population at the time of their birth.
unicef-d8.source: United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division (2019). World Population Prospects 2019, Online Edition. Rev. 1. Proportion of urban population for regions and growth rates for total and urban population calculated by UNICEF.

unicef-d9.def: Number of years newborn children would live if subject to the mortality risks prevailing for the cross section of population at the time of their birth.
unicef-d9.source: United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division (2019). World Population Prospects 2019, Online Edition. Rev. 1. Proportion of urban population for regions and growth rates for total and urban population calculated by UNICEF.

unicef-d10.def: Number of years newborn children would live if subject to the mortality risks prevailing for the cross section of population at the time of their birth.
unicef-d10.source: United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division (2019). World Population Prospects 2019, Online Edition. Rev. 1. Proportion of urban population for regions and growth rates for total and urban population calculated by UNICEF.

unicef-d11.def: The total dependency ratio is the ratio of the sum of the population aged 0-14 and that aged 65+ to the population aged 15-64. The child dependency ratio is the ratio of the population aged 0-14 to the population aged 15-64. The old-age dependency ratio is the ratio of the population aged 65 years or over to the population aged 15-64. All ratios are presented as number of dependants per 100 persons of working age (15-64).
unicef-d11.source: United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division (2019). World Population Prospects 2019, Online Edition. Rev. 1. Proportion of urban population for regions and growth rates for total and urban population calculated by UNICEF.

unicef-d12.def: The total dependency ratio is the ratio of the sum of the population aged 0-14 and that aged 65+ to the population aged 15-64. The child dependency ratio is the ratio of the population aged 0-14 to the population aged 15-64. The old-age dependency ratio is the ratio of the population aged 65 years or over to the population aged 15-64. All ratios are presented as number of dependants per 100 persons of working age (15-64).
unicef-d12.source: United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division (2019). World Population Prospects 2019, Online Edition. Rev. 1. Proportion of urban population for regions and growth rates for total and urban population calculated by UNICEF.

unicef-d13.def: The total dependency ratio is the ratio of the sum of the population aged 0-14 and that aged 65+ to the population aged 15-64. The child dependency ratio is the ratio of the population aged 0-14 to the population aged 15-64. The old-age dependency ratio is the ratio of the population aged 65 years or over to the population aged 15-64. All ratios are presented as number of dependants per 100 persons of working age (15-64).
unicef-d13.source: United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division (2019). World Population Prospects 2019, Online Edition. Rev. 1. Proportion of urban population for regions and growth rates for total and urban population calculated by UNICEF.

unicef-d14.def: Urban population as a percentage of the total population.
unicef-d14.source: United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division (2019). World Population Prospects 2019, Online Edition. Rev. 1. Proportion of urban population for regions and growth rates for total and urban population calculated by UNICEF.

unicef-cm1.def: Probability of dying between birth and exactly 5 years of age, expressed per 1,000 live births.
unicef-cm1.source: United Nations Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, World Health Organization, United Nations Population Division and the World Bank Group). Last update: 2020.

unicef-cm2.def: Probability of dying between birth and exactly 5 years of age, expressed per 1,000 live births.
unicef-cm2.source: United Nations Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, World Health Organization, United Nations Population Division and the World Bank Group). Last update: 2020.

unicef-cm3.def: Probability of dying between birth and exactly 5 years of age, expressed per 1,000 live births.
unicef-cm3.source: United Nations Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, World Health Organization, United Nations Population Division and the World Bank Group). Last update: 2020.

unicef-cm5.def: Probability of dying between birth and exactly 1 year of age, expressed per 1,000 live births.
unicef-cm5.source: United Nations Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, World Health Organization, United Nations Population Division and the World Bank Group). Last update: 2020.

unicef-cm6.def: Probability of dying during the first 28 days of life, expressed per 1,000 live births.
unicef-cm6.source: United Nations Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, World Health Organization, United Nations Population Division and the World Bank Group). Last update: 2020.

unicef-cm7.def: Infant mortality rate - Probability of dying between birth and exactly 1 year of age, expressed per 1,000 live births
unicef-cm7.source: United Nations Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, World Health Organization, United Nations Population Division and the World Bank Group). Last update: 2020.

unicef-cm8.def: Infant mortality rate - Probability of dying between birth and exactly 1 year of age, expressed per 1,000 live births
unicef-cm8.source: United Nations Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, World Health Organization, United Nations Population Division and the World Bank Group). Last update: 2020.

unicef-cm9.def: Probability of dying during the first 28 days of life, expressed per 1,000 live births
unicef-cm9.source: United Nations Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, World Health Organization, United Nations Population Division and the World Bank Group). Last update: 2020.

unicef-cm10.def: Probability of dying during the first 28 days of life, expressed per 1,000 live births
unicef-cm10.source: United Nations Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, World Health Organization, United Nations Population Division and the World Bank Group). Last update: 2020.

unicef-cm11.def: Probability of dying during the first 28 days of life, expressed per 1,000 live births
unicef-cm11.source: United Nations Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, World Health Organization, United Nations Population Division and the World Bank Group). Last update: 2020.

unicef-cm12.indicator: Mortality rate among children aged 5–14 years
unicef-cm12.def: Probability of dying at age 5–14 years expressed per 1,000 children aged 5
unicef-cm12.source: United Nations Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, World Health Organization, United Nations Population Division and the World Bank Group). Last update: 2020.

unicef-cm13.indicator: Mortality rate among children aged 5–14 years
unicef-cm13.def: Probability of dying at age 5–14 years expressed per 1,000 children aged 5
unicef-cm13.source: United Nations Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, World Health Organization, United Nations Population Division and the World Bank Group). Last update: 2020.

unicef-cm14.def: Stillbirth rate (SBR) is defined as the number of babies born with no sign of life at 28 weeks or more of gestation per 1,000 total births
unicef-cm14.source: United Nations Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, World Health Organization, United Nations Population Division and the World Bank Group). Last update: 2020.

unicef-cm15.def: Stillbirth rate (SBR) is defined as the number of babies born with no sign of life at 28 weeks or more of gestation per 1,000 total births
unicef-cm15.source: United Nations Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, World Health Organization, United Nations Population Division and the World Bank Group). Last update: 2020.

unicef-cm17.def: Number of deaths among children under 5 years of age
unicef-cm17.source: United Nations Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, World Health Organization, United Nations Population Division and the World Bank Group). Last update: 2020.

unicef-cm18.def: Number of deaths occurring within the first 28 days of life
unicef-cm18.source: United Nations Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, World Health Organization, United Nations Population Division and the World Bank Group). Last update: 2020.

unicef-cm19.indicator: Neonatal deaths as a percentage of under-five deaths
unicef-cm19.def: The percentage of under-five deaths occurring within the first 28 days of life
unicef-cm19.source: United Nations Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, World Health Organization, United Nations Population Division and the World Bank Group). Last update: 2020.

unicef-cm20.def: Number of deaths among children aged 5 to 14 years
unicef-cm20.source: United Nations Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, World Health Organization, United Nations Population Division and the World Bank Group). Last update: 2020.

unicef-cm21.source: United Nations Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, World Health Organization, United Nations Population Division and the World Bank Group). Last update: 2020.

unicef-mnh1.def: Number of years newborn female children would live if subject to the mortality risks prevailing for the cross section of population at the time of their birth.
unicef-mnh1.source: United Nations Population Division, World Population Prospects 2019. Last update: January 2021.

unicef-mnh14.def: Number of deaths of women from pregnancy-related causes (modelled estimates).
unicef-mnh14.source: United Nations Maternal Mortality Estimation Inter-agency Group (WHO, UNICEF, UNFPA, the World Bank and the United Nations Population Division). Last Update: September 2019.

unicef-mnh15.def: Number of deaths of women from pregnancy-related causes per 100,000 live births during the same time period (modelled estimates).
unicef-mnh15.source: United Nations Maternal Mortality Estimation Inter-agency Group (WHO, UNICEF, UNFPA, the World Bank and the United Nations Population Division). Last Update: September 2019.

unicef-mnh16.dim: Lifetime risk of maternal death (1 in X)
unicef-mnh16.def: Lifetime risk of maternal death takes into account both the probability of becoming pregnant and the probability of dying as a result of that pregnancy, accumulated across a woman’s reproductive years (modelled estimates).
unicef-mnh16.source: United Nations Maternal Mortality Estimation Inter-agency Group (WHO, UNICEF, UNFPA, the World Bank and the United Nations Population Division). Last Update: September 2019.

unicef-ch1.def: Percentage of live births who received bacilli Calmette−Guérin (vaccine against tuberculosis).
unicef-ch1.source: WHO and UNICEF estimates of national immunization coverage, 2018 revision. Last update: July 2019.

unicef-ch2.def: Percentage of surviving infants who received the first dose of diphtheria, pertussis and tetanus vaccine.
unicef-ch2.source: WHO and UNICEF estimates of national immunization coverage, 2018 revision. Last update: July 2019.

unicef-ch3.def: Percentage of surviving infants who received three doses of diphtheria, pertussis and tetanus vaccine.
unicef-ch3.source: WHO and UNICEF estimates of national immunization coverage, 2018 revision. Last update: July 2019.

unicef-ch4.def: Percentage of surviving infants who received three doses of the polio vaccine.
unicef-ch4.source: WHO and UNICEF estimates of national immunization coverage, 2018 revision. Last update: July 2019.

unicef-ch5.def: Percentage of surviving infants who received the first dose of the measles−containing vaccine.
unicef-ch5.source: WHO and UNICEF estimates of national immunization coverage, 2018 revision. Last update: July 2019.

unicef-ch6.def: Percentage of children who received the second dose of measles−containing vaccine as per national schedule.
unicef-ch6.source: WHO and UNICEF estimates of national immunization coverage, 2018 revision. Last update: July 2019.

unicef-ch7.def: Percentage of surviving infants who received three doses of hepatitis B vaccine.
unicef-ch7.source: WHO and UNICEF estimates of national immunization coverage, 2018 revision. Last update: July 2019.

unicef-ch8.def: Percentage of surviving infants who received three doses of Haemophilus influenzae type b vaccine.
unicef-ch8.source: WHO and UNICEF estimates of national immunization coverage, 2018 revision. Last update: July 2019.

unicef-ch9.def: Percentage of surviving infants who received the last dose of rotavirus vaccine as recommended.
unicef-ch9.source: WHO and UNICEF estimates of national immunization coverage, 2018 revision. Last update: July 2019.

unicef-ch10.def: Percentage of surviving infants who received three doses of pneumococcal conjugate vaccine.
unicef-ch10.source: WHO and UNICEF estimates of national immunization coverage, 2018 revision. Last update: July 2019.

unicef-ch11.def: Protection at birth (PAB) – Percentage of newborns protected at birth against tetanus with tetanus toxoid.
unicef-ch11.source: WHO and UNICEF estimates of national immunization coverage, 2018 revision. Last update: July 2019.

unicef-ah1.def: The probability of dying between exact age 10 and exact age 20, expressed per 1,000 children aged 10
unicef-ah1.source: United Nations Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, World Health Organization, United Nations Population Division and the World Bank Group). Last update: September 2020.

unicef-ah2.def: Number of deaths aged 10 to 19 years
unicef-ah2.source: United Nations Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, World Health Organization, United Nations Population Division and the World Bank Group). Last update: September 2020.

unicef-ah9.def: Percentage of girls who received the last dose of human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine per national schedule
unicef-ah9.source: WHO/UNICEF estimates of human papillomavirus (HPV) immunization coverage, 2020 revision. Last update: July 2021.

unicef-ah10.def: Percentage of adolescents ages 15−19 who had at least one alcoholic drink at any time during the last twelve months.
unicef-ah10.source: WHO estimates based on international surveys (WHS, STEPS, GENACIS, and ECAS) as well as national surveys. Last update: January 2021.

unicef-ah11.def: Percentage of adolescents ages 15−19 who had at least one alcoholic drink at any time during the last twelve months.
unicef-ah11.source: WHO estimates based on international surveys (WHS, STEPS, GENACIS, and ECAS) as well as national surveys. Last update: January 2021.

unicef-ah14.def: Percentage of school going adolescents ages 11-17 not meeting WHO recommendations on physical activity for health, i.e. doing less than 60 minutes of moderate- to vigorous-intensity physical activity daily.
unicef-ah14.source: Main data sources included the Global School-based Student Health Survey (GSHS), the Health Behaviour in School-aged Children (HBSC), and some other national surveys; Data host: WHO Global Status Report on NCDs.  Last update: January 2021.

unicef-ah15.def: Percentage of school going adolescents ages 11-17 not meeting WHO recommendations on physical activity for health, i.e. doing less than 60 minutes of moderate- to vigorous-intensity physical activity daily.
unicef-ah15.source: Main data sources included the Global School-based Student Health Survey (GSHS), the Health Behaviour in School-aged Children (HBSC), and some other national surveys; Data host: WHO Global Status Report on NCDs.  Last update: January 2021.

unicef-hivaidsic14.source: Global AIDS Monitoring and UNAIDS 2021 estimates. Last update: July 2021.

unicef-hivaidsic15.indicator: Children living with HIV receiving ART, Children 0 - 14
unicef-hivaidsic15.def: Percentage of children living with HIV who received antiretroviral therapy (ART).
unicef-hivaidsic15.source: Global AIDS Monitoring and UNAIDS 2021 estimates. Last update: July 2021.

unicef-ncwh1.def: Percentage of infants weighing less than 2,500 grams at birth.
unicef-ncwh1.source: Modelled estimates from UNICEF and WHO. Last update: May 2019.

unicef-ncwh3.indicator: Malnutrition among preschool-aged children, (0–4 years of age)
unicef-ncwh3.def: Moderate and severe: Percentage of children aged 0
unicef-ncwh3.source: 59 months who are below minus two standard deviations from median height-for-age of the WHO Child Growth Standards.

unicef-ncwh6.indicator: Malnutrition among preschool-aged children, (0–4 years of age)
unicef-ncwh6.def: Moderate and severe: Percentage of children aged 0
unicef-ncwh6.source: 59 months who are above two standard deviations from median weight-for-height of the WHO Child Growth Standards (includes severe overweight).

unicef-ncwh7.indicator: Vitamin A supplementation, full coverage, (6-59 months of age)
unicef-ncwh7.def: The estimated percentage of children aged 6
unicef-ncwh7.source: 59 months reached with 2 doses of vitamin A supplements approximately 4

unicef-ncwh8.indicator: Malnutrition among school-aged children, (5–19 years of age)
unicef-ncwh8.source: 19 years with  BMI < -2 SD of the median according to the WHO growth reference for school-age children and adolescents.

unicef-ncwh9.indicator: Malnutrition among school-aged children, (5–19 years of age)
unicef-ncwh9.source: 19 years with  BMI > 1 SD of the median according to the WHO growth reference for school-age children and adolescents.

unicef-ncwh10.def: Percentage of women 18+ years of age with a body mass index (BMI) less than 18.5 kg/m2.
unicef-ncwh10.source: NCD Risk Factor Collaboration (NCD-RisC), based on Worldwide trends in body-mass index, underweight, overweight and obesity from 1975 to 2016: a pooled analysis of 2416 population-based measurement studies in 128.9 million children, adolescents, and adults. The Lancet 2017, 390 (10113): 2627

unicef-ncwh11.def: Percentage of women aged 15−49 years with a haemoglobin concentration less than 120 g/L for non-pregnant women and lactating women, and less than 110 g/L for pregnant women, adjusted for altitude and smoking.
unicef-ncwh11.source: Global Health Observatory, WHO. Last update: April 2021

unicef-ncwh12.indicator: Percentage of households consuming iodized salt
unicef-ncwh12.def: Percentage of households consuming salt with any iodine (>0 ppm).
unicef-ncwh12.source: DHS, MICS, other national household surveys, and school-based surveys. Last update: August 2021

unicef-e21.indicator: Literacy rate, 2019, Youth (15–24 years) literacy rate
unicef-e21.def: Number of literate persons aged 15–24 years, expressed as a percentage of the total population in that group.
unicef-e21.source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (UIS). Last update: March 2021.

unicef-e22.indicator: Literacy rate, 2019, Youth (15–24 years) literacy rate
unicef-e22.def: Number of literate persons aged 15–24 years, expressed as a percentage of the total population in that group.
unicef-e22.source: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (UIS). Last update: March 2021.

unicef-wash1.indicator: Households with basic drinking water services
unicef-wash1.def: Percentage of the population using an improved drinking water source, where collection time is not more than 30 minutes for a round trip including queuing (improved sources include: piped water; boreholes or tubewells; protected dug wells; protected springs; rainwater; and packaged or delivered water).
unicef-wash1.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (JMP). Last update: July 2021.

unicef-wash2.indicator: Households with basic drinking water services
unicef-wash2.def: Percentage of the population using an improved drinking water source, where collection time is not more than 30 minutes for a round trip including queuing (improved sources include: piped water; boreholes or tubewells; protected dug wells; protected springs; rainwater; and packaged or delivered water).
unicef-wash2.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (JMP). Last update: July 2021.

unicef-wash3.indicator: Households with basic drinking water services
unicef-wash3.def: Percentage of the population using an improved drinking water source, where collection time is not more than 30 minutes for a round trip including queuing (improved sources include: piped water; boreholes or tubewells; protected dug wells; protected springs; rainwater; and packaged or delivered water).
unicef-wash3.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (JMP). Last update: July 2021.

unicef-wash4.def: Percentage of the population using an improved sanitation facility that is not shared with other households. Improved facilities include: flush/pour flush to piped sewerage systems, septic tanks or pit latrines; ventilated improved pit latrines; composting toilets or pit latrines with slabs.
unicef-wash4.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (JMP). Last update: July 2021.

unicef-wash5.def: Percentage of the population using an improved sanitation facility that is not shared with other households. Improved facilities include: flush/pour flush to piped sewerage systems, septic tanks or pit latrines; ventilated improved pit latrines; composting toilets or pit latrines with slabs.
unicef-wash5.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (JMP). Last update: July 2021.

unicef-wash6.def: Percentage of the population using an improved sanitation facility that is not shared with other households. Improved facilities include: flush/pour flush to piped sewerage systems, septic tanks or pit latrines; ventilated improved pit latrines; composting toilets or pit latrines with slabs.
unicef-wash6.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (JMP). Last update: July 2021.

unicef-wash7.def: Percentage of the population with a handwashing facility with water and soap available on premises.
unicef-wash7.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (JMP). Last update: July 2021.

unicef-wash8.def: Percentage of the population with a handwashing facility with water and soap available on premises.
unicef-wash8.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (JMP). Last update: July 2021.

unicef-wash9.def: Percentage of the population with a handwashing facility with water and soap available on premises.
unicef-wash9.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (JMP). Last update: July 2021.

unicef-wash10.def: Percentage of schools with drinking water from an improved source available at the time of the survey.
unicef-wash10.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (JMP). Last update: July 2021.

unicef-wash11.def: Percentage of schools with drinking water from an improved source available at the time of the survey.
unicef-wash11.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (JMP). Last update: July 2021.

unicef-wash12.def: Percentage of schools with drinking water from an improved source available at the time of the survey.
unicef-wash12.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (JMP). Last update: July 2021.

unicef-wash13.def: Percentage of schools with improved sanitation facilities, which are single-sex and usable.
unicef-wash13.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (JMP). Last update: July 2021.

unicef-wash14.def: Percentage of schools with improved sanitation facilities, which are single-sex and usable.
unicef-wash14.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (JMP). Last update: July 2021.

unicef-wash15.def: Percentage of schools with improved sanitation facilities, which are single-sex and usable.
unicef-wash15.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (JMP). Last update: July 2021.

unicef-wash16.def: Percentage of schools with handwashing facilities with water and soap available.
unicef-wash16.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (JMP). Last update: July 2021.

unicef-wash17.def: Percentage of schools with handwashing facilities with water and soap available.
unicef-wash17.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (JMP). Last update: July 2021.

unicef-wash18.def: Percentage of schools with handwashing facilities with water and soap available.
unicef-wash18.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (JMP). Last update: July 2021.

unicef-wash19.indicator: Healthcare facilities with basic water services
unicef-wash19.def: Percentage of health care facilities with drinking water from an improved source available at the time of the survey.
unicef-wash19.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (JMP). Last update: July 2021.

unicef-wash20.indicator: Healthcare facilities with basic sanitation services
unicef-wash20.def: Percentage of health care facilities with basic sanitation services. Improved facilities include: flush/pour flush to piped sewerage systems, septic tanks or pit latrines; ventilated improved pit latrines; composting toilets or pit latrines with slabs.
unicef-wash20.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (JMP). Last update: July 2021.

unicef-wash21.indicator: Healthcare facilities with basic hygiene services
unicef-wash21.def: Percentage of health care facilities with a handwashing facility with water and soap available on premises.
unicef-wash21.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (JMP). Last update: July 2021.

unicef-wash22.indicator: Healthcare facilities with basic waste management services
unicef-wash22.def: Percentage of health care facilities where waste is safely segregated into at least three bins, and sharps and infectious waste are treated and disposed of safely.
unicef-wash22.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (JMP). Last update: July 2021.

unicef-a1.source: United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division (2019). World Population Prospects 2019, Online Edition.

The Lancet 2017, 390 (10113): 2627

The Lancet 2017, 390 (10113): 2627

unicef-a8.def: Percentage of children and young people at the end of lower secondary achieving at least a minimum proficiency level in math.

unicef-a11.source: United Nations Statistics Division. Last update: April 2019.

unicef-wee2.indicator: Legal frameworks on gender equality in employment
unicef-wee2.def: Measures as a percentage of achivement from 0 to 100 with 100 being best practice, government efforts to put in place legal frameworks that promote, enforce and monitor gender equality in the area of employment and economic benefits.
unicef-wee2.source: UN Women, World Bank Group, OECD Development Centre. Last update: May 2021

unicef-m1.def: The number of people born in a country other than that in which they live, including refugees.
unicef-m1.source: United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division (2020). International Migrant Stock 2020.

unicef-m2.def: The number of people born in a country other than that in which they live, including refugees.
unicef-m2.source: United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division (2020). International Migrant Stock 2020.

unicef-m3.dim: Total as share of national population
unicef-m3.def: The number of people born in a country other than that in which they live, including refugees.
unicef-m3.source: United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division (2020). International Migrant Stock 2020.

unicef-m4.def: Persons who are forced to flee their home country to escape persecution or a serious threat to their life, physical integrity or freedom. Numbers in this table refer to refugees under UNHCR mandate only. Additional Palestine refugees registered with UNRWA are present in State of Palestine, Lebanon, Syria, and Jordan but are not listed here.
unicef-m4.source: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, Global Trends: Forced Displacement in 2020, UNHCR, Geneva, 2021

Numbers in this table refer to refugees under UNHCR mandate only. Additional Palestine refugees registered with UNRWA are present in State of Palestine, Lebanon, Syria, and Jordan but are not listed here.

Numbers in this table refer to refugees under UNHCR mandate only. Additional Palestine refugees registered with UNRWA are present in State of Palestine, Lebanon, Syria, and Jordan but are not listed here.
unicef-m6.source: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, Global Trends: Forced Displacement in 2020, UNHCR, Geneva, 2023

Numbers in this table refer to refugees under UNHCR mandate only. Additional Palestine refugees registered with UNRWA are present in State of Palestine, Lebanon, Syria, and Jordan but are not listed here.
unicef-m9.source: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, Global Trends: Forced Displacement in 2020, UNHCR, Geneva, 2026

unicef-m10.def: Persons who have been forced or obliged to flee or to leave their homes or places of habitual residence and who have not crossed an internationally recognized state border at a given point in time.
unicef-m10.source: Internal Displacement Monitoring Centre, Global Internal Displacement Database (GIDD), IDMC, 2021.

unicef-m11.def: Persons who have been forced or obliged to flee or to leave their homes or places of habitual residence and who have not crossed an internationally recognized state border at a given point in time.
unicef-m11.source: Internal Displacement Monitoring Centre, Global Internal Displacement Database (GIDD), IDMC, 2021.

unicef-m12.dim: Share due to conflict and violence
unicef-m12.def: Persons who have been forced or obliged to flee or to leave their homes or places of habitual residence and who have not crossed an internationally recognized state border at a given point in time.
unicef-m12.source: Internal Displacement Monitoring Centre, Global Internal Displacement Database (GIDD), IDMC, 2021.

unicef-m14.def: Number of movements of persons who have been forced or obliged to flee or to leave their homes or places of habitual residence and who have not crossed an internationally recognized state border in a given period.
unicef-m14.source: Internal Displacement Monitoring Centre, Global Internal Displacement Database (GIDD), IDMC, 2021.

unicef-m15.def: Number of movements of persons who have been forced or obliged to flee or to leave their homes or places of habitual residence and who have not crossed an internationally recognized state border in a given period.
unicef-m15.source: Internal Displacement Monitoring Centre, Global Internal Displacement Database (GIDD), IDMC, 2021.

unicef-m16.dim: Share due to conflict and violence
unicef-m16.def: Number of movements of persons who have been forced or obliged to flee or to leave their homes or places of habitual residence and who have not crossed an internationally recognized state border in a given period.
unicef-m16.source: Internal Displacement Monitoring Centre, Global Internal Displacement Database (GIDD), IDMC, 2021.

unicef-m17.def: Number of movements of persons who have been forced or obliged to flee or to leave their homes or places of habitual residence and who have not crossed an internationally recognized state border in a given period.
unicef-m17.source: Internal Displacement Monitoring Centre, Global Internal Displacement Database (GIDD), IDMC, 2021.

pci-energy.def: This category measures the availability, sustainability and efficiency of power sources. For this reason, it is composed by use and access to energy, losses in distribution and renewability of energy components and sources, and includes the GDP generated by each unit of oil to highlight further the importance of optimal energy systems.

pci-humanCapital.def: Human capital captures the education, skills and health conditions possessed by population, and the overall research and development integration in the texture of society through the number of researchers and expenditure on research activities. The gender dimension is reflected by the fertility rate which at each increase reduces human capital score.
pci-humanCapital.source:
UNDP
UNESCO Institute for Statistics
United Nations Population Division: World Population Prospects (2019 revision) 
Census reports and other statistical publications from national statistical offices 
Eurostat demographic statistics 
United Nations Statistics Division, population and vital statistics report (various years) International database, Census Bureau, United States of America 
Secretariat of the Pacific Community statistics and demography programme

pci-icts.def: Information and Communication Technology estimates the accessibility and integration of communication systems within the population. It includes fixed line and mobile phones users, internet accessibility and server security.
pci-icts.source:
International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication/ICT Development Report and database
World Development Indicators (infrastructure)

pci-institutions.def: Institutions aim at measuring political stability and efficiency through its regulatory quality, effectiveness, success in fighting criminality, corruption and terrorism, and safeguard of citizens’ freedom of expression and association.

pci-naturalCapital.def: Natural capital estimates the availability of extractive and agricultural resources, including rents generated from the extraction of the natural resource, less the cost of extracting the resource. To capture commodity dependence, natural capital decreases as the material intensity increases.
pci-naturalCapital.source:
Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
http://www.materialflows.net/
UNCTAD
Sustainable Development Goals data

pci-privateSector.def: Private sector is defined by the ease of cross-border trade, which includes time and monetary costs to export and import, and the support to business in terms of domestic credit, velocity of contract enforcement and time required to start a business.
pci-privateSector.source:
World Bank Doing Business project
WIPO
World Development Indicators

pci-structuralChange.def: Structural change refers to the movement of labour and other productive resources from low-productivity to high-productivity economic activities. This shift is currently captured by the sophistication and variety of exports, the intensity of fixed capital and the weight of industry and services on total GDP. Structural change can also happen within a given sector provided that binding constraints in a particular sector are identified and effectively addressed.

pci-transport.def: Transport measures the capability of a system to take people or goods from one place to another. It is defined as the capillarity of roads and railway network and air connectivity.
pci-transport.source:
International Civil Aviation Organization
International Road Federation, World Road Statistics
UNCTAD computation based on data from the International Civil Aviation Organization

pci-pci.def: The PCI is the first comprehensive attempt to measure productive capacities in all economies and construct a multidimensional index that can provide country-specific insights and diagnostics of productive capacity development.
pci-pci.source: See https://unctad.org/system/files/official-document/aldc2020d3_en.pdf for full list of sources

wdi-EG.CFT.ACCS.ZS.indicator: Access to clean fuels and technologies for cooking
wdi-EG.CFT.ACCS.ZS.def: Access to clean fuels and technologies for cooking is the proportion of total population primarily using clean cooking fuels and technologies for cooking. Under WHO guidelines, kerosene is excluded from clean cooking fuels.
wdi-EG.CFT.ACCS.ZS.source: World Bank, Sustainable Energy for All (SE4ALL) database from WHO Global Household Energy database.

wdi-EG.ELC.ACCS.ZS.def: Access to electricity is the percentage of population with access to electricity. Electrification data are collected from industry, national surveys and international sources.
wdi-EG.ELC.ACCS.ZS.source: World Bank Global Electrification Database from "Tracking SDG 7: The Energy Progress Report" led jointly by the custodian agencies: the International Energy Agency (IEA), the International Renewable Energy Agency (IRENA), the United Nations Statistics Division (UNSD), the World Bank and the World Health Organization (WHO).

wdi-EG.ELC.ACCS.RU.ZS.def: Access to electricity, rural is the percentage of rural population with access to electricity.
wdi-EG.ELC.ACCS.RU.ZS.source: World Bank Global Electrification Database from "Tracking SDG 7: The Energy Progress Report" led jointly by the custodian agencies: the International Energy Agency (IEA), the International Renewable Energy Agency (IRENA), the United Nations Statistics Division (UNSD), the World Bank and the World Health Organization (WHO).

wdi-EG.ELC.ACCS.UR.ZS.def: Access to electricity, urban is the percentage of urban population with access to electricity.
wdi-EG.ELC.ACCS.UR.ZS.source: World Bank Global Electrification Database from "Tracking SDG 7: The Energy Progress Report" led jointly by the custodian agencies: the International Energy Agency (IEA), the International Renewable Energy Agency (IRENA), the United Nations Statistics Division (UNSD), the World Bank and the World Health Organization (WHO).

wdi2-NY.ADJ.NNTY.KD.ZG.def: Adjusted net national income is GNI minus consumption of fixed capital and natural resources depletion.
wdi2-NY.ADJ.NNTY.KD.ZG.source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods described in the World Bank's The Changing Wealth of Nations.

wdi2-NY.ADJ.NNTY.KD.def: Adjusted net national income is GNI minus consumption of fixed capital and natural resources depletion.
wdi2-NY.ADJ.NNTY.KD.source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods described in the World Bank's The Changing Wealth of Nations.

wdi2-NY.ADJ.NNTY.CD.def: Adjusted net national income is GNI minus consumption of fixed capital and natural resources depletion.
wdi2-NY.ADJ.NNTY.CD.source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods described in the World Bank's The Changing Wealth of Nations.

wdi2-NY.ADJ.NNTY.PC.KD.ZG.indicator: Adjusted net national income per capita
wdi2-NY.ADJ.NNTY.PC.KD.ZG.def: Adjusted net national income is GNI minus consumption of fixed capital and natural resources depletion.
wdi2-NY.ADJ.NNTY.PC.KD.ZG.source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods in World Bank's "The Changing Wealth of Nations: Measuring Sustainable Development in the New Millennium" (2011).

wdi2-NY.ADJ.NNTY.PC.KD.indicator: Adjusted net national income per capita
wdi2-NY.ADJ.NNTY.PC.KD.def: Adjusted net national income is GNI minus consumption of fixed capital and natural resources depletion.
wdi2-NY.ADJ.NNTY.PC.KD.source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods in World Bank's "The Changing Wealth of Nations: Measuring Sustainable Development in the New Millennium" (2011).

wdi2-NY.ADJ.NNTY.PC.CD.indicator: Adjusted net national income per capita
wdi2-NY.ADJ.NNTY.PC.CD.def: Adjusted net national income is GNI minus consumption of fixed capital and natural resources depletion.
wdi2-NY.ADJ.NNTY.PC.CD.source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods in World Bank's "The Changing Wealth of Nations: Measuring Sustainable Development in the New Millennium" (2011).

wdi2-NY.ADJ.SVNX.GN.ZS.def: Adjusted net savings are equal to net national savings plus education expenditure and minus energy depletion, mineral depletion, net forest depletion, and carbon dioxide. This series excludes particulate emissions damage.
wdi2-NY.ADJ.SVNX.GN.ZS.source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods described in the World Bank's The Changing Wealth of Nations.

wdi2-NY.ADJ.SVNG.GN.ZS.def: Adjusted net savings are equal to net national savings plus education expenditure and minus energy depletion, mineral depletion, net forest depletion, and carbon dioxide and particulate emissions damage.
wdi2-NY.ADJ.SVNG.GN.ZS.source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods described in the World Bank's The Changing Wealth of Nations.

wdi2-NY.ADJ.DCO2.GN.ZS.def: Cost of damage due to carbon dioxide emissions from fossil fuel use and the manufacture of cement, estimated to be US$40 per ton of CO2 (the unit damage in 2017 US dollars for CO2 emitted in 2020) times the number of tons of CO2 emitted.
wdi2-NY.ADJ.DCO2.GN.ZS.source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods described in the World Bank's The Changing Wealth of Nations.

wdi2-NY.ADJ.DKAP.GN.ZS.def: Consumption of fixed capital represents the replacement value of capital used up in the process of production.
wdi2-NY.ADJ.DKAP.GN.ZS.source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods described in the World Bank's The Changing Wealth of Nations.

wdi2-NY.ADJ.AEDU.GN.ZS.def: Education expenditure refers to the current operating expenditures in education, including wages and salaries and excluding capital investments in buildings and equipment.
wdi2-NY.ADJ.AEDU.GN.ZS.source: UNESCO; data are extrapolated to the most recent year available

wdi2-NY.ADJ.DNGY.GN.ZS.def: Energy depletion is the ratio of the value of the stock of energy resources to the remaining reserve lifetime. It covers coal, crude oil, and natural gas.
wdi2-NY.ADJ.DNGY.GN.ZS.source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods described in the World Bank's The Changing Wealth of Nations.

wdi2-NY.ADJ.ICTR.GN.ZS.def: Gross savings are the difference between gross national income and public and private consumption, plus net current transfers.
wdi2-NY.ADJ.ICTR.GN.ZS.source: World Bank national accounts data files.

wdi2-NY.ADJ.DMIN.GN.ZS.def: Mineral depletion is the ratio of the value of the stock of mineral resources to the remaining reserve lifetime. It covers tin, gold, lead, zinc, iron, copper, nickel, silver, bauxite, and phosphate.
wdi2-NY.ADJ.DMIN.GN.ZS.source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods described in the World Bank's The Changing Wealth of Nations.

wdi2-NY.ADJ.DRES.GN.ZS.def: Natural resource depletion is the sum of net forest depletion, energy depletion, and mineral depletion. Net forest depletion is unit resource rents times the excess of roundwood harvest over natural growth. Energy depletion is the ratio of the value of the stock of energy resources to the remaining reserve lifetime. It covers coal, crude oil, and natural gas. Mineral depletion is the ratio of the value of the stock of mineral resources to the remaining reserve lifetime. It covers tin, gold, lead, zinc, iron, copper, nickel, silver, bauxite, and phosphate.
wdi2-NY.ADJ.DRES.GN.ZS.source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods described in the World Bank's The Changing Wealth of Nations.

wdi2-NY.ADJ.DFOR.GN.ZS.def: Net forest depletion is calculated as the product of unit resource rents and the excess of roundwood harvest over natural growth. If growth exceeds harvest, this figure is zero.
wdi2-NY.ADJ.DFOR.GN.ZS.source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods described in the World Bank's The Changing Wealth of Nations.

wdi2-NY.ADJ.NNAT.GN.ZS.def: Net national savings are equal to gross national savings less the value of consumption of fixed capital.
wdi2-NY.ADJ.NNAT.GN.ZS.source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods described in the World Bank's The Changing Wealth of Nations.

wdi2-NY.ADJ.DPEM.GN.ZS.def: Particulate emissions damage is the damage due to exposure of a country's population to ambient concentrations of particulates measuring less than 2.5 microns in diameter (PM2.5), ambient ozone pollution, and indoor concentrations of PM2.5 in households cooking with solid fuels. Damages are calculated as foregone labor income due to premature death. Estimates of health impacts from the Global Burden of Disease Study 2019. Data for other years have been extrapolated from trends in mortality rates.
wdi2-NY.ADJ.DPEM.GN.ZS.source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods described in the World Bank's The Changing Wealth of Nations.

wdi2-SP.ADO.TFRT.def: Adolescent fertility rate is the number of births per 1,000 women ages 15-19.
wdi2-SP.ADO.TFRT.source: United Nations Population Division, World Population Prospects.

wdi2-SP.POP.DPND.def: Age dependency ratio is the ratio of dependents--people younger than 15 or older than 64--to the working-age population--those ages 15-64. Data are shown as the proportion of dependents per 100 working-age population.
wdi2-SP.POP.DPND.source: World Bank staff estimates based on age distributions of United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects: 2019 Revision.

wdi2-SP.POP.DPND.OL.def: Age dependency ratio, old, is the ratio of older dependents--people older than 64--to the working-age population--those ages 15-64. Data are shown as the proportion of dependents per 100 working-age population.
wdi2-SP.POP.DPND.OL.source: World Bank staff estimates based on age distributions of United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects: 2019 Revision.

wdi2-SP.POP.DPND.YG.def: Age dependency ratio, young, is the ratio of younger dependents--people younger than 15--to the working-age population--those ages 15-64. Data are shown as the proportion of dependents per 100 working-age population.
wdi2-SP.POP.DPND.YG.source: World Bank staff estimates based on age distributions of United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects: 2019 Revision.

wdi-AG.LND.AGRI.ZS.def: Agricultural land refers to the share of land area that is arable, under permanent crops, and under permanent pastures. Arable land includes land defined by the FAO as land under temporary crops (double-cropped areas are counted once), temporary meadows for mowing or for pasture, land under market or kitchen gardens, and land temporarily fallow. Land abandoned as a result of shifting cultivation is excluded. Land under permanent crops is land cultivated with crops that occupy the land for long periods and need not be replanted after each harvest, such as cocoa, coffee, and rubber. This category includes land under flowering shrubs, fruit trees, nut trees, and vines, but excludes land under trees grown for wood or timber. Permanent pasture is land used for five or more years for forage, including natural and cultivated crops.
wdi-AG.LND.AGRI.ZS.source: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wdi-AG.LND.AGRI.K2.def: Agricultural land refers to the share of land area that is arable, under permanent crops, and under permanent pastures. Arable land includes land defined by the FAO as land under temporary crops (double-cropped areas are counted once), temporary meadows for mowing or for pasture, land under market or kitchen gardens, and land temporarily fallow. Land abandoned as a result of shifting cultivation is excluded. Land under permanent crops is land cultivated with crops that occupy the land for long periods and need not be replanted after each harvest, such as cocoa, coffee, and rubber. This category includes land under flowering shrubs, fruit trees, nut trees, and vines, but excludes land under trees grown for wood or timber. Permanent pasture is land used for five or more years for forage, including natural and cultivated crops.
wdi-AG.LND.AGRI.K2.source: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wdi-AG.AGR.TRAC.NO.def: Agricultural machinery refers to the number of wheel and crawler tractors (excluding garden tractors) in use in agriculture at the end of the calendar year specified or during the first quarter of the following year.
wdi-AG.AGR.TRAC.NO.source: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wdi-AG.LND.TRAC.ZS.dim: tractors per 100 sq. km of arable land
wdi-AG.LND.TRAC.ZS.units: tractors per 100 sq. km of arable land
wdi-AG.LND.TRAC.ZS.def: Agricultural machinery refers to the number of wheel and crawler tractors (excluding garden tractors) in use in agriculture at the end of the calendar year specified or during the first quarter of the following year. Arable land includes land defined by the FAO as land under temporary crops (double-cropped areas are counted once), temporary meadows for mowing or for pasture, land under market or kitchen gardens, and land temporarily fallow. Land abandoned as a result of shifting cultivation is excluded.
wdi-AG.LND.TRAC.ZS.source: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wdi-EN.ATM.METH.AG.ZS.def: Agricultural methane emissions are emissions from animals, animal waste, rice production, agricultural waste burning (nonenergy, on-site), and savanna burning.
wdi-EN.ATM.METH.AG.ZS.source: World Bank staff estimates from original source: European Commission, Joint Research Centre (JRC)/Netherlands Environmental Assessment Agency (PBL). Emission Database for Global Atmospheric Research (EDGAR): http://edgar.jrc.ec.europa.eu/.

wdi-EN.ATM.METH.AG.KT.CE.dim: thousand metric tons of CO2 equivalent
wdi-EN.ATM.METH.AG.KT.CE.units: thousand metric tons of CO2 equivalent
wdi-EN.ATM.METH.AG.KT.CE.def: Agricultural methane emissions are emissions from animals, animal waste, rice production, agricultural waste burning (nonenergy, on-site), and savanna burning.
wdi-EN.ATM.METH.AG.KT.CE.source: Data for up to 1990 are sourced from Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center, Environmental Sciences Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Tennessee, United States. Data from 1990 are CAIT data: Climate Watch. 2020. GHG Emissions. Washington, DC: World Resources Institute. Available at: https://www.climatewatchdata.org/ghg-emissions.

wdi-EN.ATM.NOXE.AG.ZS.def: Agricultural nitrous oxide emissions are emissions produced through fertilizer use (synthetic and animal manure), animal waste management, agricultural waste burning (nonenergy, on-site), and savanna burning.
wdi-EN.ATM.NOXE.AG.ZS.source: World Bank staff estimates from original source: European Commission, Joint Research Centre (JRC)/Netherlands Environmental Assessment Agency (PBL). Emission Database for Global Atmospheric Research (EDGAR): http://edgar.jrc.ec.europa.eu/.

wdi-EN.ATM.NOXE.AG.KT.CE.dim: thousand metric tons of CO2 equivalent
wdi-EN.ATM.NOXE.AG.KT.CE.units: thousand metric tons of CO2 equivalent
wdi-EN.ATM.NOXE.AG.KT.CE.def: Agricultural nitrous oxide emissions are emissions produced through fertilizer use (synthetic and animal manure), animal waste management, agricultural waste burning (nonenergy, on-site), and savanna burning.
wdi-EN.ATM.NOXE.AG.KT.CE.source: Data for up to 1990 are sourced from Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center, Environmental Sciences Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Tennessee, United States. Data from 1990 are CAIT data: Climate Watch. 2020. GHG Emissions. Washington, DC: World Resources Institute. Available at: https://www.climatewatchdata.org/ghg-emissions.

wdi2-TX.VAL.AGRI.ZS.UN.def: Agricultural raw materials comprise SITC section 2 (crude materials except fuels) excluding divisions 22, 27 (crude fertilizers and minerals excluding coal, petroleum, and precious stones), and 28 (metalliferous ores and scrap).
wdi2-TX.VAL.AGRI.ZS.UN.source: World Bank staff estimates through the WITS platform from the Comtrade database maintained by the United Nations Statistics Division.

wdi2-TM.VAL.AGRI.ZS.UN.def: Agricultural raw materials comprise SITC section 2 (crude materials except fuels) excluding divisions 22, 27 (crude fertilizers and minerals excluding coal, petroleum, and precious stones), and 28 (metalliferous ores and scrap).
wdi2-TM.VAL.AGRI.ZS.UN.source: World Bank staff estimates through the WITS platform from the Comtrade database maintained by the United Nations Statistics Division.

wdi2-NV.AGR.TOTL.ZS.def: Agriculture corresponds to ISIC divisions 1-5 and includes forestry, hunting, and fishing, as well as cultivation of crops and livestock production. Value added is the net output of a sector after adding up all outputs and subtracting intermediate inputs. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or depletion and degradation of natural resources. The origin of value added is determined by the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC), revision 3. Note: For VAB countries, gross value added at factor cost is used as the denominator.
wdi2-NV.AGR.TOTL.ZS.source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wdi2-NV.AGR.TOTL.KD.ZG.def: Annual growth rate for agricultural value added based on constant local currency. Aggregates are based on constant 2010 U.S. dollars. Agriculture corresponds to ISIC divisions 1-5 and includes forestry, hunting, and fishing, as well as cultivation of crops and livestock production. Value added is the net output of a sector after adding up all outputs and subtracting intermediate inputs. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or depletion and degradation of natural resources. The origin of value added is determined by the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC), revision 3.
wdi2-NV.AGR.TOTL.KD.ZG.source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wdi2-NV.AGR.TOTL.KD.def: Agriculture corresponds to ISIC divisions 1-5 and includes forestry, hunting, and fishing, as well as cultivation of crops and livestock production. Value added is the net output of a sector after adding up all outputs and subtracting intermediate inputs. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or depletion and degradation of natural resources. The origin of value added is determined by the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC), revision 3. Data are in constant 2010 U.S. dollars.
wdi2-NV.AGR.TOTL.KD.source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wdi2-NV.AGR.TOTL.CD.def: Agriculture corresponds to ISIC divisions 1-5 and includes forestry, hunting, and fishing, as well as cultivation of crops and livestock production. Value added is the net output of a sector after adding up all outputs and subtracting intermediate inputs. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or depletion and degradation of natural resources. The origin of value added is determined by the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC), revision 3. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wdi2-NV.AGR.TOTL.CD.source: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wdi2-NV.AGR.EMPL.KD.def: Value added per worker is a measure of labor productivity—value added per unit of input. Value added denotes the net output of a sector after adding up all outputs and subtracting intermediate inputs. Data are in constant 2010 U.S. dollars. Agriculture corresponds to the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC) tabulation categories A and B (revision 3) or tabulation category A (revision 4), and includes forestry, hunting, and fishing as well as cultivation of crops and livestock production.
wdi2-NV.AGR.EMPL.KD.source: Derived using World Bank national accounts data and OECD National Accounts data files, and employment data from International Labour Organization, ILOSTAT database.

wdi-IS.AIR.GOOD.MT.K1.def: Air freight is the volume of freight, express, and diplomatic bags carried on each flight stage (operation of an aircraft from takeoff to its next landing), measured in metric tons times kilometers traveled.
wdi-IS.AIR.GOOD.MT.K1.source: International Civil Aviation Organization, Civil Aviation Statistics of the World and ICAO staff estimates.

wdi-IS.AIR.PSGR.def: Air passengers carried include both domestic and international aircraft passengers of air carriers registered in the country.
wdi-IS.AIR.PSGR.source: International Civil Aviation Organization, Civil Aviation Statistics of the World and ICAO staff estimates.

wdi-IS.AIR.DPRT.def: Registered carrier departures worldwide are domestic takeoffs and takeoffs abroad of air carriers registered in the country.
wdi-IS.AIR.DPRT.source: International Civil Aviation Organization, Civil Aviation Statistics of the World and ICAO staff estimates.

wdi-EG.USE.COMM.CL.ZS.def: Clean energy is noncarbohydrate energy that does not produce carbon dioxide when generated. It includes hydropower and nuclear, geothermal, and solar power, among others.

wdi-ER.H2O.FWAG.ZS.def: Annual freshwater withdrawals refer to total water withdrawals, not counting evaporation losses from storage basins. Withdrawals also include water from desalination plants in countries where they are a significant source. Withdrawals can exceed 100 percent of total renewable resources where extraction from nonrenewable aquifers or desalination plants is considerable or where there is significant water reuse. Withdrawals for agriculture are total withdrawals for irrigation and livestock production. Data are for the most recent year available for 1987-2002.
wdi-ER.H2O.FWAG.ZS.source: Food and Agriculture Organization, AQUASTAT data.

wdi-ER.H2O.FWDM.ZS.def: Annual freshwater withdrawals refer to total water withdrawals, not counting evaporation losses from storage basins. Withdrawals also include water from desalination plants in countries where they are a significant source. Withdrawals can exceed 100 percent of total renewable resources where extraction from nonrenewable aquifers or desalination plants is considerable or where there is significant water reuse. Withdrawals for domestic uses include drinking water, municipal use or supply, and use for public services, commercial establishments, and homes. Data are for the most recent year available for 1987-2002.
wdi-ER.H2O.FWDM.ZS.source: Food and Agriculture Organization, AQUASTAT data.

wdi-ER.H2O.FWIN.ZS.def: Annual freshwater withdrawals refer to total water withdrawals, not counting evaporation losses from storage basins. Withdrawals also include water from desalination plants in countries where they are a significant source. Withdrawals can exceed 100 percent of total renewable resources where extraction from nonrenewable aquifers or desalination plants is considerable or where there is significant water reuse. Withdrawals for industry are total withdrawals for direct industrial use (including withdrawals for cooling thermoelectric plants). Data are for the most recent year available for 1987-2002.
wdi-ER.H2O.FWIN.ZS.source: Food and Agriculture Organization, AQUASTAT data.

wdi-ER.H2O.FWTL.ZS.def: Annual freshwater withdrawals refer to total water withdrawals, not counting evaporation losses from storage basins. Withdrawals also include water from desalination plants in countries where they are a significant source. Withdrawals can exceed 100 percent of total renewable resources where extraction from nonrenewable aquifers or desalination plants is considerable or where there is significant water reuse. Withdrawals for agriculture and industry are total withdrawals for irrigation and livestock production and for direct industrial use (including withdrawals for cooling thermoelectric plants). Withdrawals for domestic uses include drinking water, municipal use or supply, and use for public services, commercial establishments, and homes. Data are for the most recent year available for 1987-2002.
wdi-ER.H2O.FWTL.ZS.source: Food and Agriculture Organization, AQUASTAT data.

wdi-ER.H2O.FWTL.K3.def: Annual freshwater withdrawals refer to total water withdrawals, not counting evaporation losses from storage basins. Withdrawals also include water from desalination plants in countries where they are a significant source. Withdrawals can exceed 100 percent of total renewable resources where extraction from nonrenewable aquifers or desalination plants is considerable or where there is significant water reuse. Withdrawals for agriculture and industry are total withdrawals for irrigation and livestock production and for direct industrial use (including withdrawals for cooling thermoelectric plants). Withdrawals for domestic uses include drinking water, municipal use or supply, and use for public services, commercial establishments, and homes. Data are for the most recent year available for 1987-2002.
wdi-ER.H2O.FWTL.K3.source: Food and Agriculture Organization, AQUASTAT data.

wdi2-SH.HIV.ARTC.ZS.def: Antiretroviral therapy coverage indicates the percentage of all people living with HIV who are receiving antiretroviral therapy.

wdi2-SH.HIV.PMTC.ZS.units: % of pregnant women living with HIV
wdi2-SH.HIV.PMTC.ZS.def: Percentage of pregnant women with HIV who receive antiretroviral medicine for prevention of mother-to-child transmission (PMTCT).

wdi-ER.FSH.AQUA.MT.def: Aquaculture is understood to mean the farming of aquatic organisms including fish, molluscs, crustaceans and aquatic plants. Aquaculture production specifically refers to output from aquaculture activities, which are designated for final harvest for consumption.

wdi-AG.LND.ARBL.ZS.def: Arable land includes land defined by the FAO as land under temporary crops (double-cropped areas are counted once), temporary meadows for mowing or for pasture, land under market or kitchen gardens, and land temporarily fallow. Land abandoned as a result of shifting cultivation is excluded.
wdi-AG.LND.ARBL.ZS.source: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wdi-AG.LND.ARBL.HA.PC.def: Arable land (hectares per person) includes land defined by the FAO as land under temporary crops (double-cropped areas are counted once), temporary meadows for mowing or for pasture, land under market or kitchen gardens, and land temporarily fallow. Land abandoned as a result of shifting cultivation is excluded.
wdi-AG.LND.ARBL.HA.PC.source: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wdi2-SH.STA.ARIC.ZS.units: % of children under 5 taken to a health provider
wdi2-SH.STA.ARIC.ZS.def: Children with acute respiratory infection (ARI) who are taken to a health provider refers to the percentage of children under age five with ARI in the last two weeks who were taken to an appropriate health provider, including hospital, health center, dispensary, village health worker, clinic, and private physician.
wdi2-SH.STA.ARIC.ZS.source: UNICEF, State of the World's Children, Childinfo, and Demographic and Health Surveys.

wdi-MS.MIL.TOTL.TF.ZS.def: Armed forces personnel are active duty military personnel, including paramilitary forces if the training, organization, equipment, and control suggest they may be used to support or replace regular military forces. Labor force comprises all people who meet the International Labour Organization's definition of the economically active population.
wdi-MS.MIL.TOTL.TF.ZS.source: International Institute for Strategic Studies, The Military Balance.

wdi-MS.MIL.TOTL.P1.def: Armed forces personnel are active duty military personnel, including paramilitary forces if the training, organization, equipment, and control suggest they may be used to support or replace regular military forces.
wdi-MS.MIL.TOTL.P1.source: International Institute for Strategic Studies, The Military Balance.

wdi-MS.MIL.XPRT.KD.def: Arms transfers cover the supply of military weapons through sales, aid, gifts, and those made through manufacturing licenses. Data cover major conventional weapons such as aircraft, armored vehicles, artillery, radar systems, missiles, and ships designed for military use. Excluded are transfers of other military equipment such as small arms and light weapons, trucks, small artillery, ammunition, support equipment, technology transfers, and other services. Figures are SIPRI Trend Indicator Values (TIVs) expressed in US$ m.  A '0' indicates that the value of deliveries is less than US$0.5m
wdi-MS.MIL.XPRT.KD.source: Stockholm International Peace Research Institute (SIPRI), Arms Transfers Programme (http://portal.sipri.org/publications/pages/transfer/splash).

wdi-MS.MIL.MPRT.KD.def: Arms transfers cover the supply of military weapons through sales, aid, gifts, and those made through manufacturing licenses. Data cover major conventional weapons such as aircraft, armored vehicles, artillery, radar systems, missiles, and ships designed for military use. Excluded are transfers of other military equipment such as small arms and light weapons, trucks, small artillery, ammunition, support equipment, technology transfers, and other services. Figures are SIPRI Trend Indicator Values (TIVs) expressed in US$ m. A '0' indicates that the value of deliveries is less than US$0.5m.
wdi-MS.MIL.MPRT.KD.source: Stockholm International Peace Research Institute (SIPRI), Arms Transfers Programme (http://portal.sipri.org/publications/pages/transfer/splash).

wdi-FB.ATM.TOTL.P5.def: Automated teller machines are computerized telecommunications devices that provide clients of a financial institution with access to financial transactions in a public place.
wdi-FB.ATM.TOTL.P5.source: International Monetary Fund, Financial Access Survey.

wdi-IC.TAX.METG.indicator: Number of visits or required meetings with tax officials
wdi-IC.TAX.METG.def: Average number of visits or required meetings with tax officials during the year. The value represents the average number of visits for all firms which reported being visited or required to meet with tax officials (please see indicator IC.FRM.METG.ZS).

wdi-IC.CUS.DURS.EX.indicator: Average time to clear exports through customs
wdi-IC.CUS.DURS.EX.def: Average time to clear exports through customs is the average number of days to clear direct exports through customs.

wdi-FD.RES.LIQU.AS.ZS.indicator: Bank liquid reserves to bank assets ratio
wdi-FD.RES.LIQU.AS.ZS.def: Ratio of bank liquid reserves to bank assets is the ratio of domestic currency holdings and deposits with the monetary authorities to claims on other governments, nonfinancial public enterprises, the private sector, and other banking institutions.
wdi-FD.RES.LIQU.AS.ZS.source: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wdi-EN.BIR.THRD.NO.def: Birds are listed for countries included within their breeding or wintering ranges. Threatened species are the number of species classified by the IUCN as endangered, vulnerable, rare, indeterminate, out of danger, or insufficiently known.
wdi-EN.BIR.THRD.NO.source: United Nations Environmental Program and the World Conservation Monitoring Centre, and International Union for Conservation of Nature, Red List of Threatened Species.

wdi2-SP.DYN.CBRT.IN.def: Crude birth rate indicates the number of live births per 1,000 midyear population.
wdi2-SP.DYN.CBRT.IN.source: (1) United Nations Population Division. World Population Prospects: 2019 Revision. (2) Census reports and other statistical publications from national statistical offices, (3) Eurostat: Demographic Statistics, (4) United Nations Statistical Division. Population and Vital Statistics Reprot (various years), (5) U.S. Census Bureau: International Database, and (6) Secretariat of the Pacific Community: Statistics and Demography Programme.

wdi2-SH.STA.BRTC.ZS.indicator: Births attended by skilled health staff
wdi2-SH.STA.BRTC.ZS.def: Births attended by skilled health staff are the percentage of deliveries attended by personnel trained to give the necessary supervision, care, and advice to women during pregnancy, labor, and the postpartum period; to conduct deliveries on their own; and to care for newborns.
wdi2-SH.STA.BRTC.ZS.source: UNICEF, State of the World's Children, Childinfo, and Demographic and Health Surveys.

wdi-FB.CBK.BRWR.P3.def: Borrowers from commercial banks are the reported number of resident customers that are nonfinancial corporations (public and private) and households who obtained loans from commercial banks and other banks functioning as commercial banks. For many countries data cover the total number of loan accounts due to lack of information on loan account holders.
wdi-FB.CBK.BRWR.P3.source: International Monetary Fund, Financial Access Survey.

wdi-IC.FRM.BRIB.ZS.units: % of firms experiencing at least one bribe payment request
wdi-IC.FRM.BRIB.ZS.def: Bribery incidence is the percentage of firms experiencing at least one bribe payment request across 6 public transactions dealing with utilities access, permits, licenses, and taxes.

wdi-FM.LBL.BMNY.GD.ZS.def: Broad money (IFS line 35L..ZK) is the sum of currency outside banks; demand deposits other than those of the central government; the time, savings, and foreign currency deposits of resident sectors other than the central government; bank and traveler’s checks; and other securities such as certificates of deposit and commercial paper.
wdi-FM.LBL.BMNY.GD.ZS.source: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

wdi-IC.BUS.DISC.XQ.def: Disclosure index measures the extent to which investors are protected through disclosure of ownership and financial information. The index ranges from 0 to 10, with higher values indicating more disclosure.

wdi-ER.FSH.CAPT.MT.def: Capture fisheries production measures the volume of fish catches landed by a country for all commercial, industrial, recreational and subsistence purposes.

wdi2-SH.DTH.COMM.ZS.indicator: Cause of death, by communicable diseases and maternal, prenatal and nutrition conditions
wdi2-SH.DTH.COMM.ZS.def: Cause of death refers to the share of all deaths for all ages by underlying causes. Communicable diseases and maternal, prenatal and nutrition conditions include infectious and parasitic diseases, respiratory infections, and nutritional deficiencies such as underweight and stunting.
wdi2-SH.DTH.COMM.ZS.source: Derived based on the data from Global Health Estimates 2020: Deaths by Cause, Age, Sex, by Country and by Region, 2000-2019. Geneva, World Health Organization; 2020. Link: https://www.who.int/data/gho/data/themes/mortality-and-global-health-estimates/ghe-leading-causes-of-death

wdi2-SH.DTH.INJR.ZS.def: Cause of death refers to the share of all deaths for all ages by underlying causes. Injuries include unintentional and intentional injuries.
wdi2-SH.DTH.INJR.ZS.source: Derived based on the data from Global Health Estimates 2020: Deaths by Cause, Age, Sex, by Country and by Region, 2000-2019. Geneva, World Health Organization; 2020. Link: https://www.who.int/data/gho/data/themes/mortality-and-global-health-estimates/ghe-leading-causes-of-death

wdi2-SH.DTH.NCOM.ZS.def: Cause of death refers to the share of all deaths for all ages by underlying causes. Non-communicable diseases include cancer, diabetes mellitus, cardiovascular diseases, digestive diseases, skin diseases, musculoskeletal diseases, and congenital anomalies.
wdi2-SH.DTH.NCOM.ZS.source: Derived based on the data from Global Health Estimates 2020: Deaths by Cause, Age, Sex, by Country and by Region, 2000-2019. Geneva, World Health Organization; 2020. Link: https://www.who.int/data/gho/data/themes/mortality-and-global-health-estimates/ghe-leading-causes-of-death

wdi-AG.PRD.CREL.MT.def: Production data on cereals relate to crops harvested for dry grain only. Cereal crops harvested for hay or harvested green for food, feed, or silage and those used for grazing are excluded.
wdi-AG.PRD.CREL.MT.source: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wdi-AG.YLD.CREL.KG.def: Cereal yield, measured as kilograms per hectare of harvested land, includes wheat, rice, maize, barley, oats, rye, millet, sorghum, buckwheat, and mixed grains. Production data on cereals relate to crops harvested for dry grain only. Cereal crops harvested for hay or harvested green for food, feed, or silage and those used for grazing are excluded.
wdi-AG.YLD.CREL.KG.source: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wdi-BM.GSR.ROYL.CD.indicator: Charges for the use of intellectual property
wdi-BM.GSR.ROYL.CD.def: Charges for the use of intellectual property are payments and receipts between residents and nonresidents for the authorized use of proprietary rights (such as patents, trademarks, copyrights, industrial processes and designs including trade secrets, and franchises) and for the use, through licensing agreements, of produced originals or prototypes (such as copyrights on books and manuscripts, computer software, cinematographic works, and sound recordings) and related rights (such as for live performances and television, cable, or satellite broadcast). Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wdi-BM.GSR.ROYL.CD.source: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wdi-BX.GSR.ROYL.CD.indicator: Charges for the use of intellectual property
wdi-BX.GSR.ROYL.CD.def: Charges for the use of intellectual property are payments and receipts between residents and nonresidents for the authorized use of proprietary rights (such as patents, trademarks, copyrights, industrial processes and designs including trade secrets, and franchises) and for the use, through licensing agreements, of produced originals or prototypes (such as copyrights on books and manuscripts, computer software, cinematographic works, and sound recordings) and related rights (such as for live performances and television, cable, or satellite broadcast). Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wdi-BX.GSR.ROYL.CD.source: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wdi2-SH.MLR.TRET.ZS.indicator: Children with fever receiving antimalarial drugs
wdi2-SH.MLR.TRET.ZS.units: % of children under age 5 with fever
wdi2-SH.MLR.TRET.ZS.def: Malaria treatment refers to the percentage of children under age five who were ill with fever in the last two weeks and received any appropriate (locally defined) anti-malarial drugs.
wdi2-SH.MLR.TRET.ZS.source: UNICEF, State of the World's Children, Childinfo, and Demographic and Health Surveys.

wdi-FS.AST.CGOV.GD.ZS.def: Claims on central government (IFS line 52AN or 32AN) include loans to central government institutions net of deposits.
wdi-FS.AST.CGOV.GD.ZS.source: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

wdi-EN.ATM.CO2E.KD.GD.def: Carbon dioxide emissions are those stemming from the burning of fossil fuels and the manufacture of cement. They include carbon dioxide produced during consumption of solid, liquid, and gas fuels and gas flaring.
wdi-EN.ATM.CO2E.KD.GD.source: Data for up to 1990 are sourced from Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center, Environmental Sciences Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Tennessee, United States. Data from 1990 are CAIT data: Climate Watch. 2020. GHG Emissions. Washington, DC: World Resources Institute. Available at: https://www.climatewatchdata.org/ghg-emissions. See NY.GDP.MKTP.KD for the denominator's source.

wdi-EN.ATM.CO2E.PP.GD.KD.def: Carbon dioxide emissions are those stemming from the burning of fossil fuels and the manufacture of cement. They include carbon dioxide produced during consumption of solid, liquid, and gas fuels and gas flaring.
wdi-EN.ATM.CO2E.PP.GD.KD.source: Data for up to 1990 are sourced from Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center, Environmental Sciences Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Tennessee, United States. Data from 1990 are CAIT data: Climate Watch. 2020. GHG Emissions. Washington, DC: World Resources Institute. Available at: https://www.climatewatchdata.org/ghg-emissions. See NY.GDP.MKTP.PP.KD for the denominator's source.

wdi-EN.ATM.CO2E.PP.GD.def: Carbon dioxide emissions are those stemming from the burning of fossil fuels and the manufacture of cement. They include carbon dioxide produced during consumption of solid, liquid, and gas fuels and gas flaring.
wdi-EN.ATM.CO2E.PP.GD.source: Data for up to 1990 are sourced from Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center, Environmental Sciences Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Tennessee, United States. Data from 1990 are CAIT data: Climate Watch. 2020. GHG Emissions. Washington, DC: World Resources Institute. Available at: https://www.climatewatchdata.org/ghg-emissions. See NY.GDP.MKTP.PP.CD for the denominator's source.

wdi-EN.ATM.CO2E.KT.units: thousand metric tons of CO2 excluding Land-Use Change and Forestry
wdi-EN.ATM.CO2E.KT.def: Carbon dioxide emissions are those stemming from the burning of fossil fuels and the manufacture of cement. They include carbon dioxide produced during consumption of solid, liquid, and gas fuels and gas flaring.
wdi-EN.ATM.CO2E.KT.source: Data for up to 1990 are sourced from Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center, Environmental Sciences Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Tennessee, United States. Data from 1990 are CAIT data: Climate Watch. 2020. GHG Emissions. Washington, DC: World Resources Institute. Available at: https://www.climatewatchdata.org/ghg-emissions.
